name: USGS Principal Aquifers of the United States

properties.name: Central Valley aquifer system
properties.stress_note: Up to 60 ft of land subsidence; NASA GRACE shows accelerating loss

properties.name: High Plains aquifer (Ogallala)
properties.stress_note: Water levels declined 160+ ft on average; some TX/KS areas depleted 50%+

properties.name: Pecos River Basin alluvial aquifer
properties.stress_note: Significant depletion from irrigation; Pecos River flows greatly reduced

properties.name: Mississippi River Valley alluvial aquifer
properties.stress_note: One of the most pumped aquifers in the US; water table declining in Arkansas delta

properties.name: Seymour aquifer
properties.stress_note: Heavily used for irrigated agriculture; significant water table declines in droughts

properties.name: Long Island - Upper Glacial Aquifer
properties.stress_note: Saltwater intrusion threat from over-pumping near coastlines; contamination from legacy development

properties.name: Long Island - Magothy Aquifer
properties.stress_note: Primary drinking water source for 3M+ people; contamination plumes from industrial sites

properties.name: Long Island - Lloyd Aquifer
properties.stress_note: Deepest and most protected LI aquifer; used as emergency reserve. Saltwater intrusion risk if over-pumped.

properties.name: Long Island - Jameco Aquifer
properties.stress_note: Limited extent in southern Nassau County; saltwater intrusion observed

properties.name: Texas coastal uplands aquifer system
properties.stress_note: Subsidence observed in Houston area from historical overpumping

properties.name: Northern Atlantic Coastal Plain aquifer system
Floridan aquifer system
properties.stress_note: Spring flows reduced significantly; saltwater intrusion in coastal areas

properties.name: Edwards-Trinity aquifer system
properties.stress_note: Springs have ceased flowing during droughts; regulated by Edwards Aquifer Authority

properties.name: New York and New England carbonate-rock aquifers
Piedmont and Blue Ridge carbonate-rock aquifers
Great Basin carbonate and alluvial aquifer system
Midwestern basins and arches aquifer system
Piedmont and Blue Ridge crystalline-rock aquifers
New York and New England crystalline-rock aquifers
Carrizo-Wilcox Aquifer
properties.stress_note: Water levels have declined 150+ ft in 30 years in heavily pumped areas of central Texas
